captions.text: Hmm hmm hmm…reading my book like a good guy. Oh! OH HAI GUISE!
I didn't see you come in! It's the Spudgy here.
Well, it's been really rainy lately
so I think I'm going to go to Seoul.
There's this cool cafe where you can bring your humans,
Isn't that great?  Let's, let's, let's go guise!
I just, uhhhh, oh.  I can't get down from here.
Can you guise help me out a second?

title: Bau House Dog Cafe in Seoul

comments.author: khricket

comments.text:
"Pet culture", as Simon and Martina call it, is new to Korea. There just 
aren't very many dogs at all in general, and most of them get fixed, so it 
makes sense that most of the dogs you see will be purebred.

comments.author: Phuong Pham

comments.text:
I know your comment is old, but I wanted to mention that it is perfectly 
safe and fine to use a collar leash on a dog that is well behaved and 
doesn't pull, like Spudgy! A dog like mine who is constantly pulling 
towards the next big thing when he's on his leash obviously requires a 
harness everytime he goes out, but Spudgy is obviously well-behaved and a 
harness isn't a necessity (although he does have one).
comments.author: Marie Moore

comments.text:
+Phuong Pham But you can see Spudgy has a harness also there isn't anything 
wrong with them my sister uses those for her small dogs and they're 
perfectly healthy and they never cry in pain when she walks them for her 
big dogs she just uses normal ones
comments.author: ShawolSecretTime

comments.text:
+Phuong Pham Oh, my bad. I didn't know it was a flexi leash! Never heard of 
them, actually. Sorry :P
comments.author: AnthieGG

comments.text:
and btw i did not say anything bad about "normal" leashes i meant those 
flexi leashes that she used in this video.
comments.author: Phuong Pham

comments.text:
i might sound a bit rude (and english is obviously not my first language) 
but i just want all dogs to have it even better :P
comments.author: Phuong Pham

comments.text:
+Phuong Pham A leash can only harm a dog if the leash is not at the top of 
the neck, actually. I'm not sure if it says that in the article but as long 
as the leash is at the top of the neck, it won't injure them! But if you're 
really paranoid of the necklace going down the neck, a harness is good, 
too. Just wanted to let you know :D
comments.author: AnthieGG

comments.text:
+ayumihamano
http://dogmantics.com/2013/07/17/is-it-harmful-to-attach-a-leash-to-your-dogs-neck-2/
comments.author: Phuong Pham

comments.text:
a dog's neck is similar to our necks, so imagine yourself having a necklace 
and a flexi leash that "pulls" your neck even if you just want to take a 
few steps. what's even worse is when you click on that "button" to prevent 
your dog from walking any further!! it's like someone is pulling your neck 
really hard from behind when you least expect it. that would hurt right? 
it's worse for small breed dogs because their necks are obviously small and 
not as strong.

also another thing! i think it's better to put a comfortable harness on 
your dog for taking walks instead of a necklace. my two dogs never use 
necklaces - nothing that would strangle them in any kind of way. just 
take some research on this and you will probably understand what i'm 
talking about :)
comments.author: Phuong Pham

comments.text: why would that leash be painful?

comments.text:
Omigosh I wish I knew about this place when I lived in Korea. We got out 
dog in Korea from a Korean vet in dongducheon. He was 2 months old and a 
Rottweiler/German Shepard mix. Surprising bc they aren't too fond of large 
breed dogs. We took him home w us to the USA and he is now a little over 2 
years old. :))))﻿
